name: Fort Matanzas National Monument
description: Fort Matanzas National Monument preserves the fortified coquina watchtower, completed in 1742, which defended the southern approach to the Spanish military settlement of St. Augustine. It also protects approximately 300 acres of Florida coastal environment containing dunes, marsh, maritime forest, and associated flora and fauna, including threatened and endangered species.
shortDescription: Fort Matanzas National Monument preserves the fortified coquina watchtower, completed in 1742, which defended the southern approach to the Spanish military settlement of St. Augustine. It also protect...

operatingHours.description:
NO FERRY SERVICE TO FORT MATANZAS ON TUESDAYS OR WEDNESDAYS

The outdoor areas at the Fort Matanzas Visitor Center Area are open from 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Public restrooms, nature trails, fishing access, and basic visitor information and orientation services are available.

Fort tours are running Thursday through Monday with limited capacity. Boarding passes are available on a first come, first served basis. Tours may fill up early in the day.

No oversized parking is available.

fees.title: Timed Entry Reservation - Location
fees.description: All areas of the park are free of charge including the ferry to the fort. However, you must stop in the Fort Matanzas Visitor Center (NOT the St. Augustine city Visitor Center) to get your free boarding pass for the ferry. Family members of all ages must have a pass to board the ferry. Passes are Free

climate.weatherDescription: Summers are hot and humid with afternoon thundershowers. Sunscreen, a hat, UV protective sunglasses, and are recommended. Drink plenty of water. Winters are cool to mild with some cold spells, especially with wind from the north or off the water. Fall and spring are temperate with temperatures around 70F-80F (21C-26C). During danger of lightning, the fort will be closed and ferry service will be suspended. June-November is hurricane season so check for tropical storms before visiting.

images.title: Fort Matanzas
images.altText: Fort Matanzas, a fortified watch tower made form coquina.
images.caption: Fort Matanzas sits on Rattlesnake Island in the middle of the Matanzas River.

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: Two story building with stone base and wood second floor, oak trees, grass, two signs.
images.caption: Here you can find information about the fort tour, exhibits, park movie, passport stamp, and more.

images.title: Nature Trail
images.altText: A nature trail boardwalk with seating area.
images.caption: Follow an elevated boardwalk through some pristine Florida barrier island habitat.

images.title: Soldier's Quarters
images.altText: Wooden bunks and uniform items in the soldier's quarters.
images.caption: The few enlisted soldiers at Fort Matanzas shared a small, sparse room as living space.

images.title: Protecting the riverway
images.altText: The cannon of Fort Matanzas point toward the river's inlet.
images.caption: Fort Matanzas protected the southern river approach to Saint Augustine.

images.title: Recreational Opportunities
images.altText: People wading in the river and relaxing on the beach.
images.caption: More the half-a-million people visit Fort Matanzas each year to enjoy both the river and ocean beaches.
